title: TV reporter fired after he kept jumping on rare vintage cars on air
text:
TV reporter Angel Cardenas was fired after he kept jumping on rare vintage cars on air (Picture: KMAX-TV/Good Day Sacramento)

A TV reporter was fired after he repeatedly jumped on rare vintage cars while broadcasting live on air.

Angel Cardenas was filming a segment at the Sacramento International Auto Show the for the CBS morning show ‘Good Day Sacramento’ on Sunday.

Cardenas opens by saying that no one was at the car show yet except for the media coordinator and a Ford representative, so he says he plans to ‘completely wing it’ – and that’s exactly what he did.

‘So no one is out here to tell me which car I can’t go in because, you know, some of these are off limits. So I’m going to live on the wild side,’ he says, before hopping on a yellow Ford Thunderbird.

‘I feel like a kid in a candy store without the owner because you can do anything,’ Cardenas said. He then opens another car’s door which hits a pink Thunderbird.

‘Nobody’s looking. Hold on, zoom in. It’s not dented, is it? There’s no paint?’ he asks the reporters off camera.

Cardenas was apparently not done violating the display cars, so he later jumps on a Ford SUV hybrid after the Ford representative said she may ‘look the other way.’

‘Oh my god,’ the off-camera reporter shouts as Cardenas leaps onto the SUV, causing a the hood to buckle audibly.

‘That didn’t sound good,’ Cardenas said.

‘I would get off that now,’ another reporter says. Cardenas then looks off camera and says, ‘Oh no, he told me to get off.’

Cardenas’s last swan dive onto a car came at the end of the segment, when he entered a display for a newer Ford and leaped on the hood. (Picture: Good Morning Sacramento)

‘I’m going to get in trouble. Back to you guys,’ he concludes, rightly assuming that he would in fact get in trouble for leaping on privately owned and considerably expensive cars.

The two reporters in the studio are both seen with their heads in their hands in apparent disbelief before quickly changing the topic to Ford’s new line of 2020 models.

Representatives from the International Auto Show later reached out to KMAX TV about the creditworthy segment. It was later announced that he was fired.

The Sacramento International Auto Show wrote on Facebook: ‘After the Producer of the Sacramento International Auto Show reached out to the General Manager of KMAX TV regarding yesterday’s astonishingly awful incident, she received a call this morning from the GM that the reporter from the Good Day Sacramento segment has been terminated immediately and the station expressed their sincerest apologies for the incident.’
description: Angel Cardenas was fired for a segment at the Sacramento International Auto Sow the for the CBS morning show 'Good Day Sacramento.'
